comments.commentBody:

TY Nhart for the clarification! :)

But NHart, in Texas you can go out to dinner for a DWI class, pay the fine and have it wiped off your record once a year.  Or to a comedy hour, or even take out a DVD from the library.  One free drunk driving pass per year, and concealed handguns.  What a mix!

Texas is DWI-only. Quaint, but intoxicated includes all manner of substances, not just BEER in BOTTLES, which brings me to the clue for LEGALESE. Very nice, says this lawyer.

Good puzzle with all those ten-letter stacks. Happy to see all those baseball references. Spring training starts next week!

I hope one day that my solving will be as smooth as Mr. Silk's puzzles.

Untrue. Santorum, though Catholic speaks the evangelical line. Even the conservatives in the Vatican, let alone the American bishops, affirm global warning, recommend taking measures to address it, oppose the death penalty, affirm evolution, condemned the war in Iraq, and have profound questions about the form capitalism has taken in America. Santorum fails on all these counts. His Catholicism is selective and abridged.

Not only that, Santorum has not been attracting the Catholic vote at all. His support, once again is predominantly from social conservatives, particularly evangelical Christians. The numbers were especially striking in New Hampshire, where I think he got-I'm relying on memory, something like 8% of the Catholic vote.

What I'm saying Ross, is that it is important if you are to accuse others of narrowness and ignorance, that you take steps to inform yourself about the matters at hand, in this case, about Catholic teaching.

You might also read Gary Wills blog in the New York Review of Books on the Bishops for a dissenting view from a leading Catholic thinker. James Carroll's condemnation of the bishops politicizing of contraception in the Boston Globe represents another such voice.

What I'm saying is, don't stoke the fires of the already overheated rhetoric of these infernal culture wars.

As for the article. Good going, Mr. Nocera: Santorum resembles nothing so much as a modern day Puritan.

Brian -

You are confusing two issues. One is the role of religion in government, the other is Santorum's specific political beliefs. Whether he attracts the "catholic vote" or not is irrelevant, as are the views of members of the Catholic church.

The fact is a majority of Catholics support abortion rights and contraception. My guess it that the Church, as opposed to the Bishops, views on gay marriage closely parallel the rest of the country. But the most recent polls I have seen show they also support the death penalty. In other words Catholic beliefs closely parallel the rest of country.

But, as one Bishop has famously said, "the church is not a democracy". The only views that matter, in the view of the Bishops, are the Bishop's. Santorum accepts that point of view. That is different than suggesting that Santorum accepts the Bishop's public policy positions carte blanche.

It is also very different than the views of the Puritans who saw the church as a whole as the ultimate repository of God's will to which its leaders were subservient. Much as James Carroll argued in his article, it it is the one I recall reading.

I also suggest that, if you want to end the "cultural wars", you not assume people you disagree with are ignorant. They may just have thought about the subject more than you have.

@Brian: This has been said over and over by atheists, but it just never gets through to religious folks:

No church should stick its nose into government business. That means it cannot "take measures" that are for government alone to take. Outside of the church walls, it may not oppose the death penalty, condemn the war in Iraq, or "have profound questions about the form capitalism has taken in America."

If the church thinks it's time to "affirm" thing such as global warming or evolution," well...that's just great. But keep the opinions -- fair or stupid -- among the flock of believers.

Further, your use of "culture wars" is troubling. Religion and culture are not synonynous. Religion is only a part of culture -- sometimes. Atheists have no religion, yet we have a culture.

Santorum's beliefs are not based on the puritans. They are based on the belief that government is subservient to the Princes of the Church, the Bishops, who represent God's will here on earth. He believes in neither democratic government nor the validity of religious beliefs that are contrary to the Bishops.

But its a mistake to think he can't be elected. The fall election could very well be a referendum on Obama, with the qualities of his opponent largely irrelevant.

Yo! Pally, Get your facts straight, no Oopsies allowed!

Just kiddin wit ya, FB, actually, I think you're swell!

No surprises here for me. Let's see... we evaluate the work in China based on our culture and politics.  Last time we did that in an Asian country, if i recall correctly, was Viet Nam.  And we all know how that turned out.  What works for us isn't necessarily in the interests of other cultures.  Sure it would be nice if the conditions, pay, benefits, etc. were better in China, but then we wouldn't be able to afford all the stuff we buy that is made there.

Surely, goodness and mercy, our man Martin wouldn't dream of going for the lowest common denominator, as he's a gentleman of the old school without peer, especially in these enviable environs!

This is where the Republican has been heading ever since Richard Nixon. Nixon formulated the "Southern strategy," which pointed the party in the direction of the racist moral dregs of American society. Since then the Republcan Party has been morally and intellectually bankrupt. Sooner or later a 3rd party will claim the vacated middle ground, relegating the GOP to the status of far-right spoiler.

This is such a propagandistic account of what took place including the photo which was clearly intended to undermine the Romney event.   I heard on a cable TV network that what actually took place was that a small annex of the stadium had been booked by the local Republic group but the Secret Service asked that the site be relocated for security reasons and that's why it ended up where it was.

The president of the Detroit Economic Club response:

"I just heard that there is some confusion in the media regarding the selection of today's venue. That is very disappointing after such a terrific meeting. As I said in my remarks today, we sold out the previous venue in 90 minutes and were delighted that Ford Field was available and could accommodate the DEC. Further, we thought it a wonderful Detroit landmark to host this nationally broadcast meeting."

"The original plan was to host the Romney meeting in the atrium, which is where we host DEC meetings when at Ford Field. During our walk through with the security team there were further issues raised due to the size of the crowd so we moved the event to the field. Had we followed our normal plan in the atrium, the football field would not have been visible - and the room would have been packed."

Listening to Romney stump for the presidency is like listening to a used car salesman selling his first car.

The reality is all of the people he knows have multiple expensive cars. His point, that Cadillacs are made in the US (are they?) addresses his friends. I don't think he really gets it that most people in this country really can't afford one Cadillac and one house. But he doesn't know that.
And that is why he will never be President.
What did the first Bush in vs. Clinton in a debate was not knowing the price of milk. Anyone here think Mitt does?

Hooray! I'm so happy that the people in Detroit pretty much said to Mitt "take a hike" Putting a corporate lackey into the White House will only spell our doom. The man only seeks to promote his ego,not us.

What I find fascinating, is that all these Republican candidates don't seem to connect with anyone, and some even less than others. Can you even imagine Obama only filling 1,200 seats if he decided to give a speech in this same stadium?

Neither can I.

Yeah that's right the trouble here is the story not the reality. Good grief.

wmar,

For once we are in substantial agreement. Your description of what you call the IPCC/UNFCCC "ideology" certainly describes the essence what I call my "position" on climate change. (I can't speak for anyone else.)

However, we differ on one important point. You wrote: "…and you use science to demand policies" — claiming that that's a "problem."

It seems to me that much of science would be useless indeed if it didn't "demand policies." If I'm a spokesperson for National Institute of Health or the Center for Disease Control, and I have scientific evidence that a deadly virus could attack the populace in the foreseeable future, you bet that I'll go straight to Congress and demand policy. It would be totally irresponsible of me — in fact a dereliction of my duty — to do otherwise.

No doubt some people would accuse me of being a chicken little, but I would ignore, or, if necessary, contradict them. The stakes would be too high.

Similarly, 98% of the world's climate scientists believe in AGW. Most of them believe it is at least somewhat dangerous and we need to do something about it. Many of them, through their organizations or on their own, try to influence government policy to address the problem.

From their perspective, and mine, It would be totally irresponsible — in fact a dereliction of duty — for them to do otherwise.
